awd_titl_txt: Factors shaping the maintenance of variation in a symbiont-mediated host-enemy interaction
awd_abstract_narration: In the battle against natural enemies, it has long been thought that animals are left to their own defenses. However, recent findings indicate that some rely on the defensive services of microbial symbionts. Pea aphids, for example, harbor maternally transmitted symbionts that defend them against parasitic wasps, which are used as biological control agents against these crop pests. When assessing variation in resistance to the wasp Aphidius ervi, it appears that inherited differences are driven by the presence of bacterial Hamiltonella defensa symbionts and the types of toxin-encoding bacteriophages (viruses) they harbor. Despite significant benefits conferred by these defensive elements, their presence is not universal within natural aphid populations, suggesting costs of infection and inefficient defense under some conditions. In this study, the researchers propose to explore the forces responsible for natural variation in the presence of defensive symbionts, examining the effects of temperature and levels of parasitism on symbiont prevalence. Predictions of reduced symbiont frequencies in response to high temperatures and infrequent parasitism will be tested through extensive field-based and molecular studies that quantify temperature and both symbiont and parasite prevalence over space and time. Similar approaches will be used to test the benefits of symbionts under natural conditions.  Additionally, the investigators will elucidate the mechanisms of defense, focusing on the bacteriophage toxins that are expected to drive variation in resistance. Findings from this work will determine how these species interactions are expected to change with increasing global temperatures. They will also help in the design of more effective biological control programs, through identifying the mechanisms that crop pests employ to overcome parasitism. This research will result in the training of two graduate and several undergraduate students. Through publication and presentation at scientific meetings, and through integration into undergraduate coursework, the investigators will disseminate the findings through both traditional and novel approaches.

por.por_cntn:
There is a growing awareness that animals are frequently infected with microbes that mediate key ecological interactions. Aphids, and other insects of agricultural and medical importance, typically harbor inherited bacterial symbionts, and some symbionts are now known to confer protection against natural enemies and thus provide additional genetic variation that potentially drives rapid adaptation in response to enemy pressures. To determine whether the protective benefits identified in laboratory-based studies were important in natural populations, we conducted field-studies to the prevalence and distribution of defensive symbionts in pea aphids on two forage crops, alfalfa and clover. We found that defensive symbionts are highly dynamic both temporally and spatially, and in some populations we identified positive correlations between mortality from particular natural enemies and infection with symbionts that specifically protect against those threats.  However, in other populations, mortality did not track closely with defensive symbionts. Thus, we hypothesize that while natural enemies are likely important in influencing infection prevalence and distributions, other factors also shape symbiont dynamics, which are the focus of future studies.

We also characterized defensive symbiont strain diversity, bacteriophage diversity (a virus is required to infect one of the defensive symbionts for protective function), and enemy resistance encoded in the aphid genome and found diverse sources of resistance to parasitic wasps. We also found that specific defensive symbionts are often paired together, forming the basis for additional future work. Understanding sources and amounts of variation in resistance is important to the sustainable management of agricultural pests. Our work also shows that natural enemies can have important impacts on the aphid symbioses, and that natural enemies have counter strategies to circumvent defensive symbionts. Together these studies reveal that defensive symbioses are complex and dynamic. Our work here continues the development of the pea aphid as among the best models of defensive symbiosis, which is emerging as a phenomenon of substantial importance across plants and animals.
